Mean: The average of a set of numbers, calculated by summing all values and dividing by the count
Median: The middle value in a dataset when arranged in order
Mode: The most frequently occurring value in a dataset
Standard Deviation: A measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values
Variance: The average of the squared differences from the mean
Correlation: A statistical measure that describes the extent to which two variables are related
Regression: A statistical method for estimating relationships among variables
Hypothesis: A proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for investigation
P-value: The probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true
Confidence Interval: A range of values that likely contains the true population parameter
Sample Size: The number of observations or data points in a sample
Population: The entire group of individuals or instances about which we hope to learn
Chi-Square Test: A statistical test used to determine if there is a significant association between categorical variables
T-Test: A statistical test used to compare the means of two groups
ANOVA: Analysis of Variance - a statistical method to compare means of three or more groups
Normal Distribution: A probability distribution that is symmetric about the mean, showing data near the mean are more frequent
Outlier: A data point that differs significantly from other observations
Quartile: Values that divide a dataset into four equal parts
Percentile: A value below which a given percentage of observations fall
Skewness: A measure of the asymmetry of the probability distribution
Kurtosis: A measure of the tailedness of the probability distribution
Z-Score: The number of standard deviations a data point is from the mean
Random Variable: A variable whose value is subject to variations due to chance
Expected Value: The average value of a random variable over a large number of experiments
Probability: A measure of the likelihood that an event will occur
Bayes Theorem: A formula for calculating conditional probabilities
Sampling Error: The difference between a sample statistic and the actual population parameter
Type I Error: Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is actually true (false positive)
Type II Error: Failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is actually false (false negative)
Null Hypothesis: A hypothesis that there is no significant difference or relationship in the data
